headline.main: Seeking Help for the Body in the Well-Being of the Soul

docs.abstract: Winifred Gallagher article on link between health and spirituality; spirituality's effect on health remains more hotly debated issue in science than in rest of society; polls show most Americans think that faith and prayer benefit health and that doctors should discuss link; studies show people who attend religious services weekly live longer than those who do not; photo (special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: EARLY Sunday mornings in a chapel at Riverside Church in New York, a service begins with meditation enhanced by aromatherapy and music. The communion includes laying on of hands, an ancient rite for the sick. Finally, congregants gather in the church's new Wellness Center, where they discuss topics like nutrition and cancer. Most of the congregants are women. Whether for social or biological reasons or both, said the Rev. Diane Lacey Winley, the center's coordinator and a board member of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, ''women find it easier to use prayer and meditation to find energy, strength and healing.''

headline.main: The Issue of Free Speech, The Voice of Big Money

docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews Bill Moyers Special, Free Speech for Sale, program on power of moneyed interests in American politics; photo of Moyers (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Moyers begins ''Free Speech for Sale,'' tonight's vigorous assault on the power of moneyed interests in American politics, with the story of Cindy Watson, a Republican member of the North Carolina General Assembly who took on the state's hog farmers. When her constituents complained about the odors of hog waste and its effect on drinking water, she pushed for restrictions on the growth of hog farms, the state's biggest agricultural industry, until they cleaned up their act. Well, in the next election, Ms. Watson was cleaned away with a big-money television blitz by a group calling itself Farmers for Fairness, a euphemism for the hog growers. As long as such front groups avoid the words ''vote for'' or ''vote against,'' they are not regulated by campaign finance laws. Thus, by courtesy of a much criticized Supreme Court ruling, special interests have been granted the rights of free speech once reserved for individuals, insuring that plenty of money is available to enhance corporate welfare.
